explanation: Ampère's circuital law relates the circulation of the magnetic field around a closed loop to the electric current passing through any surface bounded by that loop. Originally formulated for steady currents, Maxwell extended it with the displacement current term to maintain consistency with charge conservation. This law is fundamental for calculating magnetic fields in symmetric geometries and forms one of Maxwell's four equations describing classical electromagnetism.

assumptions.text: Classical electromagnetic theory applies: no quantum effects, fields are continuous and differentiable.
For the original Ampère's law: steady currents only ($$\frac{\partial \vec{E}}{\partial t} = 0$$) and no time-varying electric fields.
The integration path (Amperian loop) is a closed curve in a simply-connected region of space.
For practical applications: sufficient symmetry exists such that $$\vec{B}$$ has constant magnitude and is parallel or perpendicular to $$\mathrm{d}\vec{l}$$ along the integration path.
Current sources are well-defined: current density $$\vec{J}$$ is finite and integrable over the bounded surface.
Linear, homogeneous, and isotropic medium: $$\vec{B} = \mu\,\vec{H}$$ with constant permeability $$\mu$$.

derivation.description: Begin with the empirical observation that magnetic field lines form closed loops around current-carrying conductors, unlike electric field lines which begin and end on charges.
derivation.equation: \text{Observation: Magnetic field lines encircle current sources}
